Charles Adam Weissert papers, 1893-1947
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by

did.abstract: Journalist, historical researcher from Kalamazoo, Michigan; Correspondence, research articles and notes, and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Charles A. Weissert (donor no. 2429) and came to the library in multiple accessions.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Charles Adam Weissert papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Charles A. Weissert was born Aug. 22, 1878 in Hastings, Michigan. He had a varied career as a scholar, author, journalist, and lawmaker. He was a veteran newspaperman working for newspapers in New York, Grand Rapids, Hastings, and Kalamazoo. Weissert traveled widely in his lifetime and became an authority on Michigan history, writings numerous articles and serving as an active member of the Michigan State Historical Society.

Weissert also served in the state legislature, first elected in 1914 and re-elected in 1916 and 1918. While there, he authored the bill requiring all county supervisors to use public funds for marking historical sites and preserving historical material and, as chairman of the House Committee on Military Affairs, Weissert introduced the bill establishing the Michigan State Police in 1919.

scopecontent.p: The Weissert collection includes correspondence, 1893-1947, including letters from Joseph Bailly, Clarence M. Burton, Gurdon S. Hubbard, Chase S. Osborn, Albert E. Sleeper, and George Van Pelt. There are also speeches, and writings mostly on Michigan history topics, including Indian history and the history of Kalamazoo and Barry County. The series of research notes illustrates the variety of Weissert's interests: historical personalities, forts, Michigan cities, and early state history. The photographs and snapshots pertain to Weissert's interest in Michigan history, especially homes, churches, mills, hotels, businesses, and other sites primarily in western Michigan, but also including Sault Ste. Marie and Mackinac Island. There are also photographs of Michigan pioneers, particularly from the Hastings, Michigan area.
